bibl.title: Letter from Hal R. Keeling to Philip Showalter Hench, January 29, 1948

div1.p: Keeling suggests that Hench contact a friend of Keeling's to seek more information on Reed's presentation at the American Public Health Association meeting, in 1901.

div1.head: Letter from Hal R. Keeling to Philip Showalter Hench, January 29, 1948
div1.p:
It just occurred to me that the Claypool Hotel might have been the
one in which Doctor Reed stayed.

I came to Indianapolis in 1912 and sure the Claypool hotel was over 12
years old at that time, in fact as I recall, it looked like it might have been
20 or 25 years old then.

Now, I think it would be a good idea for you to write to an Indiana-
polis newspaper man, of my acquaintance, tell him what you are up to and elicit
his cooperation on the basis that one of these days a 50th anniversary of
Doctor Reed's historic Indianapolis announcement will come along, and that some
Indianapolis paper should have all of the facts that you are now assembling.

The truth is, Phil, that this material would be a fine full-page
spread for their Indianapolis Sunday Star.

I am thinking that the Star could put a reporter looking into this
to determine exactly when the Claypool was built, whether Doctor Reed stayed
there, etc. etc.

If it turns out that he did stay there at the Claypool, then it is
possible that we could find the old register. And I believe that if the
Star went after it hard enough, they could find some old medical man who
will recall where Doctor Reed stayed, even if the register is not in existence.

In writing to my newspaper friend, I would emphasize the point that
the Indianapolis papers of April 1900 entirely missed the significance of this
historic event; I would also tell my newspaper friend about the plans of the
Republic of Cuba to set up a national memorial to Doctor Reed and emphasize
that Doctor Reed came directly from Cuba to Indianapolis to make his historic
announcement.

The man to whom I would suggest you write is Mr. James A. Stuart,
Managing Editor, Indianapolis Star, Indianapolis, Indiana. You might say
to Mr. Stuart that you are writing to him at the suggestion of a mutual friend,
namely me.

I came to Indianapolis in 1912 to work my way through Butler College
as a full time reporter on the Indianapolis Star, of which this same James A.
Stuart was then the city editor. He was almost like a father to me in those
days, counselling and guiding me in both my newspaper and college work.

We will do anything we can to dig up particular things you might want
but we don't have any where near the facilities that the Star may have. They
can command and get anything they want. And, of course, please let me know
whatever develops, as both Ray Sweeney and I will be intensely interested.
